awd_titl_txt: IRNC: RXP: StarLight SDX A Software Defined Networking Exchange for Global Science Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The StarLight Software Defined Networking Exchange (SDX) project focuses on research, development, and deployment of services, architectures, and technologies designed to provide scientists, engineers, and educators with highly advanced, diverse, reliable, persistent, and secure networking services, enabling them to optimally access resources in North America, South America, Asia, South Asia (including India), Australia, New Zealand, Europe, Africa, and other sites around the world. The StarLight SDX ensures continued innovation and development of advanced networking services and technologies. The facility supports continued research, development, experimental deployment, and trials of multi-domain SDXs and serves as an innovation platform on which to introduce next-generation services, architectures, policies, processes, and technologies, supported by persistent experimental research networking.

The project focuses on three main activities: (1) development of an SDN Development Environment - the StarAX (StarLight Advanced eXchange) Innovation Engine - that enables facilities around the world to deploy SDXs that are compatible and interoperable with others; (2) deployment of an instance of this system at the StarLight facility; and, (3) coordination and collaboration with others around the world to deploy such systems at their exchange points. This project establishes an SDN Innovation Platform (software closely integrated with select hardware) to provide multiple network functions and features quickly and reliably. This StarLight initiative builds on prior successes of the StarLight International/National Communication Exchange Facility,  and operates a wide range of emerging services and capabilities, including those based on 100 Gbps channels, programmable networking, SDN, SDX techniques, and related innovations. Northwestern University, the University of California at San Diego, and the University of Illinois at Chicago are undertaking this project in partnership with other research organizations, advanced R&E networks, and science communities around the world.

Project Outcomes Report

 

NSF International Research Network Connections (IRNC) StarLight Software Defined Exchange (SDX)

 

The StarLight SDX initiative has contributed to and expanded upon existing and emerging experimental and prototype SDN/SDX/SDI networking architectures and technologies through the development of advanced international communication services for data-intensive science, by leveraging existing designs and developments, collaborating with science-domain research communities, and investigating, experimenting with, demonstrating, and prototyping new innovations that can contribute to these communities. Scientific data generation is growing exponentially and globally, and this growth is accelerating with advances in major instrumentation, such as the HD-LHC, telescopes such as the LSST and SKA, exascale supercomputing centers, accelerators, bioinformatics facilities such as those used for the Human Genome Project, and sensor arrays.

 

The StarLight SDX initiative focused on research, development, and deployment of services, architectures, and technologies designed to provide scientists, engineers, and educators with highly advanced, diverse, reliable, persistent, and secure networking services, enabling them to optimally access, move and store large-scale data among worldwide sites. This SDX project supported the creation of next-generation, highly-distributed, scalable environments for data-intensive science – network fabrics that capture, manage, index, analyze, store, share, visualize, and transport data. Because science is global, primary foundation resources are high-performance, ultra-high-capacity networks (100s of Gbps and multiple Tbps) that support collaborating research communities worldwide. This project also developed new techniques for high degrees of network programmability and granulated customization, allowing for implementation of individualized network services and channels, for example, through segmentation and isolation of resources.

 

In partnership with researchers around the world, a major outgrowth of the StarLight SDX initiative was the development of the Global Research Platform (GRP), an international scientific collaboration that continues to develop innovative advanced ubiquitous services, integrated with large-scale data resources, around the globe. GRP collaborators work together to design, implement, and operate facilities for next-generation distributed services and infrastructure to facilitate high-performance optimal data exchange among multiple international science sites.

 

The StarLight SDX initiative supported incubation processes for novel networking services and technologies that, when proven through experiments, trials, and demonstrations, were migrated to production environments. Innovations pioneered by the StarLight SDX project have been adopted into operational practice within NRENs and open network exchanges around the world. Results have been disseminated through international community partnerships, conferences, workshops, meetings, demonstrations, publications, communication channels, and specialized forums.
